awd_titl_txt: EAGER-QAC-QSA: Quantum Algorithms for Correlated Electron-Phonon System
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Summary

In the past few decades, many unconventional quantum phenomena have been discovered in materials and molecules. These quantum many-body phenomena are expected to have revolutionary applications in functional materials, quantum information, drug discovery, and catalyst design. However, due to the complexity originating from interacting particles, a comprehensive theoretical understanding of the physics behind these phenomena is impractical even with the help of state-of-the-art supercomputers. That lack of profound understanding, in turn, hinders the design and application of these phenomena.

This EAGER award supports research and education on developing algorithms to address these quantum phenomena, with a focus on materials with strong interactions between the electrons and the vibrations of the atoms in the solid. Motivated by recent theoretical progress on this type of interaction, this project aims to develop a hybrid algorithm that takes advantage of both classical computers and existing quantum computers. In addition, the research team will also apply this new algorithm to address several specific open questions in quantum materials, including superconductivity and nonequilibrium states. This project will provide both a new class of hybrid algorithms extensible for various quantum many-body phenomena and a theoretical guideline for designing functional materials.

This project will contribute to the education and professional development of a broad pipeline of students and scholars. As a subject related to physics, computer science, chemistry, and materials science, the research outcomes will be incorporated into interdisciplinary courses. The collaboration between Clemson University and Harvard University will allow for the exchange of educational experiences with cultural and geographical diversity. Undergraduate students will be involved in the research project through summer internships or workshops, with the particular involvement of underrepresented minorities.


Technical Summary

The quantitative understanding of quantum many-body systems, especially systems with both strong electron-electron and electron-phonon interactions, is the key to many areas of science and technology. Due to the exponential growth of their Hilbert space sizes with the number of particles, a satisfactory solution for correlated systems is not accessible in classical computers and requires quantum computing techniques. Recent progress in hybrid quantum-classical algorithms constitutes a promising new direction, but the existing framework restricts their application to quantum magnets or pure fermionic systems. Therefore, the demands and difficulties motivate the development of new quantum algorithms.

This EAGER award supports research and education on developing a hybrid quantum-classical algorithm applicable to correlated electron-phonon systems, based on recent progress in the variational quantum eigensolver and the variational non-Gaussian approach. This project includes two specific goals: (i) to develop a high-accuracy quantum algorithm suitable for the ground-state calculation of electron-phonon systems; (ii) to extend the algorithm for the evaluation of dynamics and excitation spectrum. In addition to algorithm development, both goals include applications for solving cutting-edge problems in condensed matter physics, such as superconductivity and nonequilibrium states of matter.

This research will advance quantum algorithms and enable applications for systems with infinitely large Hilbert spaces. It will provide a unique tool to simulate the equilibrium and nonequilibrium properties of relevant quantum many-body systems. Moreover, the simulations based on the new algorithm will provide physical insights into understanding a few experimental phenomena, including high-Tc superconductivity and photoinduced emergent phases. These insights are crucial for the engineering and design of functional materials.

This collaborative research will provide a novel educational experience for undergraduate and graduate students at Clemson University and Harvard University. By incorporating the latest research into courses and seminars, the impact will also extend to students who are not directly involved in this project. The postdoc partially supported by this grant will receive career training in both scientific and practical skills. Through summer research and workshop activities, this project will improve science education among diverse students, particularly underrepresented minorities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary outcome of this NSF project lies in two aspects, including the development of a quantum algorithm for electron-phonon problems and the application in novel phase discoveries of quantum materials. These outcomes are reflected by 21 peer-reviewed publications.

I. Hybrid quantum algorithms and quantum simulations

Supported by this grant, the PI’s team has constructed the hybrid algorithm for electron-phonon systems based on the variational non-Gaussian transformations and demonstrated its efficiency and accuracy. We have actively applied this algorithm to explain and predict novel experiments in quantum materials. Among these applications, an important example is discovering a phonon-mediated near-neighbor attraction in cuprate compounds. Collaborating with IBM Inc., we have also implemented the hybrid quantum-classical algorithm based on the variational non-Gaussian method and the variational quantum eigensolver. 

      We have further extended the algorithm to nonequilibrium quantum dynamics by generalizing the variational parameter space. Using this generalized algorithm, we have successfully simulated the light-induced d-wave superconductivity, identifying the fluctuation nature of this nonequilibrium superconductivity. We have also advanced the algorithms related to excited-state spectral simulations by combining the cluster perturbation theory with the determinant quantum Monte Carlo approach. This embedding approach overcame the long-standing issue of limited momentum resolution of DQMC-simulated spectral functions and pushed the record to infinite resolution. It also helped to correct the bias in the traditional CPT method and reduce the finite-size effect of DQMC.

      Moreover, we designed a new quantum algorithm for optimizing deep neuron networks in transportation problems. This algorithm showed improved accuracy over its classical counterpart. This endeavor supports both research and educational objectives. We also extended the research objective from digital quantum computing to quantum simulations.

II. Applications in quantum materials with phonons

The PI’s team has also made significant progress in algorithms for quantum materials with quantum phonon contributions. In collaboration with experimental researchers, we systematically studied Ta2NiSe5, a quasi-one-dimensional material exhibiting a structural transition at room temperature. We have explained the abnormal gap in electronic states and fluctuations in diffused scattering by simulating high-temperature spectral functions with quantum phonons. This work solved a long-standing problem in understanding the phase transition in Ta2NiSe5.

      Moreover, we have also studied a novel quasi-2D material with strong electron-phonon coupling, exhibiting an unconventional hysteretic transition with a temperature range of over 400 kelvins. We also studied the coexistence of lattice and correlation effects in an iron-based superconductor. We have identified a dominant dispersionless feature and successfully assigned it to orbital excitations, highlighting the important role of electron-phonon coupling in superconductivity.

      Finally, the PI predicted special CDW orders in extremely overdoped cuprates near quarter filling and successfully verified this prediction in a thin film using x-ray scattering. We demonstrated that the electronic correlation cannot address the experimentally observed phenomenon, and it reflects the cooperation of electron-phonon couplings. We explored the Holstein-type quantum phonon model using unbiased numerical methods, revealing a complex phase diagram that featured an unexpected interplay between insulating charge density wave states and metallic phases.

Broader impacts

In addition to research achievements, the PI has mentored a diverse group of scholars, including two postdocs, five graduate students, six undergraduate students, two visiting scholars, and three high-school students, maintaining a focus on racial and sexual diversity. Each of these scholars received systematic scientific training tailored to their levels and duration of stay. The impact of this project was broadened to society through conferences, outreach activities, and public lectures. Specifically, the PI successfully organized a 4-day symposium at the Materials Research Society Meeting 2023. The PI curated a diverse panel of 29 speakers, ranging from early-career scholars to full professors, representing five countries and various racial backgrounds. This symposium was a key component of the outreach initiative promised in this grant, successfully fostering a broad exchange of knowledge and perspectives in the field. Moreover, the PI worked together with Clemson’s outreach center and hosted high-school outreach activities with the South Carolina Governer’s School for Science and Math. This activity included a public poster session inviting various college and high-school students. Finally, the PI has presented to both the scientific community and the general public, including talks at Rising Star Symposium and a lecture at Taiwan’s National Center for Theoretical Sciences.
